author: By Susanna Mälkki
title: Kaija Saariaho’s Luminous Music Was a Personal Invitation
description: The Finnish composer, who died at 70, is remembered by one of her longtime collaborators.
content: The history of classical music is a history of creators of distinct originality. Its evolution has always happened through the work of visionary individuals and their ability to expand our understanding of the world through their works. These artists widen our horizons, invent, search, open doors and create paths for others. It takes extraordinary force, and courage, to follow an inner voice that no one else knows or understands yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Will Alcaraz and Djokovic Finally Get to Play Each Other at the French Open?
description: If everything goes right in the quarterfinals Tuesday for Alcaraz and Djokovic, the two most dominant players on the men’s tour, the duel everyone has been waiting for will happen.
content: Eight days ago, 128 men began competing in singles at the French Open. Pretty much everyone has been focused on two of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Why We Write Explainers: An Explainer
description: New York Times guides to mystifying subjects may seem as if they come together in a matter of minutes, but they often take hours of research.
content: In early April, when former President Donald J. Trump was charged with 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, The New York Times published an article with the headline “The Case Against Donald Trump: What Comes Next?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Hollywood Directors Reach Deal With Studios as Writers’ Strike Continues
description: The tentative agreement includes improvements in wages and guardrails around artificial intelligence.
content: The union that represents thousands of movie and television directors reached a tentative agreement with the Hollywood studios on a three-year contract early Sunday morning, a deal that ensures labor peace with one major guild as the writers’ strike enters its sixth week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: DeSantis Relied Heavily on Big Donors in Initial Money Haul
description: The Florida governor’s campaign said it had around 40,000 donors in May, an average of more than $200 per donor — a figure far higher than is typical for a campaign heavily funded by grass-roots support.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida made a splash when he announced that he had raised a record $8.2 million in his first 24 hours as a presidential candidate. New figures disclosed by the campaign reveal that he relied heavily on larger contributors to set that record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: ‘None of Us Were Born Looking for a Screen. We Were All Born Looking for a Face.’
description: A conversation about nurturing our relationships in a digital world.
content: In the first two installments of this three-part series on the role of technology in our lives, I addressed practical questions: How do we help kids navigate a technological world? How do we discern what technology to adopt? There are also fundamental philosophical questions that new technology raises that often go unaddressed: How does technology change our understanding of what it is to be human? What assumptions does digital technology carry about what makes a good life? Our answers to these deeper questions silently guide the choices and habits we embrace in our daily lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Could Jeff Zucker Fix CNN? He Seems to Think So.
description: It’s been more than a year since he was forced from the top job at the network. Since then, he has made no secret of his frustrations with his exit — or his low regard for the man who replaced him, Chris Licht.
content: The seminar was to be on media leadership. Dozens of students filling a classroom at Yale University in April were there to learn about the business from a man who had commanded attention in TV control rooms and corporate boardrooms for decades before a stunning exit last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Silent Greeting
description: Eric Rollfing lets us in.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Phoebe Lett
title: Here’s How We Can End the War in Ukraine
description: It is time for the United States to provide Ukraine with the support it needs to win against Russia.
content: As world leaders debate how to guarantee Ukraine’s long-term security and possible admittance into NATO, the people of Kyiv are experiencing an uptick in nightly air attacks from Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Bostridge
title: Ian Bostridge on Music’s Fuzzy Boundaries of Identity
description: The beloved tenor’s latest book and album emerged from a time when the pandemic forced him to question what exactly he does when he sings.
content: Spring this year has been a particular joy for touring singers like me. The cloud of Covid seems to have evaporated: Restrictions have been lifted, audiences have (nervously) returned and the prospect of being stranded in foreign parts with a positive test is gone, not to mention the diminishing threat of serious or voice-impacting illness. Things will never be the same — they never are — but some semblance of normalcy has returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: In ‘Love + Science,’ a Meet Cute Becomes a Medical Mystery
description: In 1980s Manhattan, two medical students find themselves at the forefront of the AIDS crisis in David J. Glass’s new play at New York City Center.
content: The two medical students in “Love + Science” a new play by David J. Glass, quickly tumble into bed together and then spend five years too afraid to kiss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: In Utah, Scriptures (and Satire) Enter Debates Over Book Bans
description: In one school district, the Bible and the Book of Mormon were flagged for “sensitive materials review.”
content: Public schools are closed for the summer in Utah, leaving their libraries quieter than usual. But the books on their shelves are now the subject of a skirmish — one that is distinct from many other culture clashes over education in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Whisked Myself Down to the Street in Search of a Guy With a Clipboard’
description: Seeking a crucial hour of quiet, observations while on the D and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: In a Contentious Lawmaking Season, Red States Got Redder and Blue Ones Bluer
description: With single-party statehouse control at its highest level in decades, legislators across much of the country leaned into cultural issues and bulldozed the opposition.
content: America’s state capitals are as polarized as they have been in decades, with lawmakers imposing unflinchingly conservative or liberal agendas this year, even in politically diverse places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: From Flowing Water to Flowing Data
description: “Stream” can indicate the steady movement of virtually anything, “cacophony” included.
content: In 1926, a bootlegger arrived home on Christmas Eve to find his wife in the arms of another man. His cheerful expression changed to one of woe; tears streamed down his jowls. He retrieved a revolver from under the tree and fired two shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Republicans Gather in Iowa to Ride, Eat and Disagree
description: Eight presidential hopefuls, with Donald Trump absent, spoke at an annual political rally in Des Moines to highlight their conservative bona fides.
content: As the politicians and Republican Party officials tossed out the red meat on Saturday at an event at the Iowa State Fairgrounds, Wayne Johnson, a 70-year-old farmer and financial consultant from Forest City, Iowa, had some quieter thoughts about the next president he would like to see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Superquick Sicilian Pasta With Anchovies and Cauliflower
description: With a nutty, crunchy bread crumb topping.
content: Good morning. Anna Francese Gass has a fine new recipe for pasta with anchovies, cauliflower and nutty bread crumbs (above), her adaptation of a Sicilian pasta alla Paolina con cavolfiore from Palermo, in which you melt oil-packed anchovies in a hot pan, then combine them with tomato sauce and a blend of cinnamon and cloves. A crunchy mixture of almonds and bread crumbs goes on top. The combination is incredible, a taste of the Mediterranean that you can enjoy wherever you hang your hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Hong Kong Remembered the Tiananmen Massacre, Until It Couldn’t
description: With candlelight vigils to the victims of the 1989 crushed student uprising in Beijing now only a memory, the anniversary is also a reminder of the freedoms Hong Kong has lost.
content: For decades, Hong Kong was the only place in China where the victims of the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy activists at Tiananmen Square in Beijing could be publicly mourned in a candlelight vigil. This year, Hong Kong is notable for all the ways it is being made to forget the 1989 massacre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Macron Faces Fresh Test as Outlook for French Finances Dims
description: S&P Global restated a negative outlook for France’s ability to repay mounting debt. Two other ratings agencies have lowered their views in recent weeks.
content: To the list of challenges facing President Emmanuel Macron after raucous nationwide demonstrations over his pension measures, add a new one: a cascade of warnings over France’s finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Immense Crowds Protest Poland’s Governing Conservative Party
description: The country’s largest antigovernment gathering in years sought to reclaim the legacy of the Solidarity movement that led the struggle against a Communist system imposed by Moscow.
content: Hundreds of thousands of people marched through Warsaw on Sunday in a huge display of opposition to the governing party before an October general election, summoning memories of Poland’s rejection of Communist Party rule decades before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Vivek Shankar
title: Explosions Hit Southern Ukraine as Both Sides Brace for Counteroffensive
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky, in an unusually personal speech, urged his compatriots to show their gratitude to the country’s soldiers.
content: Explosions rang out across the front line in Ukraine on Sunday as both sides sought to gain an advantage before an expected Ukrainian campaign to retake territory captured by Russia, with the death of a 2-year-old girl underscoring the 15-month war’s enduring toll on civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louie Lazar
title: A Negro Leagues Star Is Still Sharing His Story
description: A pastor for more than 50 years, William Greason, 98, occasionally tells tales of a lifetime ago, when he mentored Willie Mays and played in the last Negro World Series.
content: The older pastor, wearing a long purple robe, ascended the steps to the pulpit. “God has always had a plan and a purpose for each of our lives,” the Rev. William H. Greason said in a slow, gentle voice. From the pews came affirmations of “Amen!” and “All right!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: What Ozempic Reveals About Desire
description: Can new weight-loss drugs curb addictions?
content: Mary Boyer, a 41-year-old tech worker, started taking the drug Mounjaro last October to treat obesity. She has since lost more than 40 pounds, going from 267 when she started to 221 when she weighed herself recently. “I’m losing, like, a pound and a half a week pretty steadily,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Your Monday Briefing: Rescue Efforts End in India Train Crash
description: Plus, Beijing is forcing Hong Kong to forget Tiananmen Square.
content: Officials investigating one of the deadliest train wrecks in India’s history were focusing on the possibility that a signal failure had caused the disaster. The crash in the eastern state of Odisha on Friday left at least 275 people dead, and more than 1,100 injured, in what officials in a preliminary government report described as a “three-way accident” involving two passenger trains and an idle freight train.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Neurodiverse Musical Theater Artist Spends Sundays
description: Sarah Kaufman writes, acts, sings and makes podcasts and TikToks — and not to mention works a day job.
content: This month, Sarah Kaufman will play the witch in the musical “Into the Woods” at the A.R.T./New York Mezzanine Theater in Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Nicholas Nehamas and Emily Cochrane
title: California Officials Investigating Flight of Migrants to Sacramento
description: The state attorney general said the migrants carried documents that specified a Florida government agency and a company that dropped migrants in Martha’s Vineyard last year.
content: Sixteen migrants from Venezuela and Colombia were abruptly flown on a private chartered jet to California and dropped off outside a church building in Sacramento on Friday, state officials said, accusing a contractor for a state-funded Florida program of transporting the group from outside a Texas migrant center under a false promise of jobs if the migrants agreed to be taken to California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Former CNN Chief Jeff Zucker Has a New Job at RedBird IMI. What Is It?
description: Mr. Zucker is C.E.O. of a $1 billion investment venture backed by RedBird Capital Partners and International Media Investments, an Emirati firm.
content: Since leaving CNN a year ago, Jeff Zucker, the network’s former president, has been on the hunt for deals, flush with $1 billion in backing from big investors in the worlds of media and finance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: The Jurors Sentenced a Missouri Man to Death. Now Some Are Not So Sure.
description: Michael Tisius was convicted of murdering two jail guards. He is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday.
content: The murders were so brazen, so brutal, they stunned the people of Missouri.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Atul Loke
title: Bodies Remain Unidentified as Relatives Struggle to Reach India Train Crash Site
description: Most of the victims’ families live in towns and villages hundreds of miles away, officials and medics said.
content: Families of the victims of India’s worst rail disaster in two decades were on Sunday still struggling to reach the town where the disaster happened. The delays meant that many bodies remain unidentified and unclaimed, local officials and doctors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: Money for Show Horses, Not Work Horses, on India’s Rails
description: Train travel in the country has gotten much safer, Friday’s disaster notwithstanding, but the government still puts high-profile projects ahead of basic safety improvements, analysts say.
content: In a country where major industry and political fortunes alike are often tied to a vast, interwoven rail system, India has lavished public resources on new trains, but its purse strings have been much tighter when it comes to ensuring the safety of those already racing along its tracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Lecher Actress Victim Spy
description: In “Lucky Dogs,” Helen Schulman spins a #MeToo case into an irreverent but surprisingly sympathetic look at two women on opposite sides of a sexual assault scandal.
content: That Harvey Weinstein hired a private international spy agency called Black Cube to help squash stories about his sex crimes always seemed stranger than fiction. Well, now it is fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather, Josh Katz and Andrew Das
title: An Unstoppable Verstappen Wins Again
description: A wire-to-wire victory for Max Verstappen in Barcelona gave Red Bull seven wins in seven starts, and renewed talk of a season sweep.
content: Lewis Hamilton drove aggressively and overtook rivals, sometimes with apparent ease. George Russell gained several places by zipping up the pit lane at the start and held off a late challenge from Sergio Pérez. It was a great day for Mercedes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Rectal Cancer Patients Could Be Spared the Brutal Effects of Radiation
description: A large “de-escalation” trial suggests that tens of thousands of people annually may be able to rely on only chemotherapy and surgery to treat their illness.
content: Rectal cancer researchers have pulled off a daunting feat, demonstrating in a large clinical trial that patients do just as well without radiation therapy as with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Who Owns the Benin Bronzes? The Answer Just Got More Complicated.
description: Restitution efforts were underway, fueled by news that a museum was being planned in Nigeria to house the treasures. Then a surprising announcement sowed uncertainty.
content: After years of ignored pleas and stonewalled requests, deals were finally coming together to return some of Africa’s most prized treasures to the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: After Walking Offstage, a Concert Pianist Changes Her Tune
description: An artist refashions herself amid personal and global crises in Deborah Levy’s new novel, “August Blue.”
content: In the work of Deborah Levy, certain elements recur in ever new arrangements: swimming, seafood, bees and silence; brokenness and recovery; the patriarchy. These themes are so consistent across Levy’s diverse body of writing, which includes poetry, plays, memoirs and novels (two of which have been Booker Prize finalists), that her real medium might be called recomposition.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 4, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 4, 2023.
content: An article on Friday about what to watch on television this weekend described incorrectly the new season of “Painting With John.” It is the third season of the show, but it has not been determined that it will be the final season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Laura Boushnak
title: No Shame. No Sorrow. Divorce Means It’s Party Time in Mauritania.
description: It is common for people in this West African desert nation to divorce many times. And when they do, the women celebrate.
content: The henna artist bent over her client’s hand, glancing at the smartphone to get the precise details of the pattern chosen by her customer, a young woman living in an ancient desert city in the West African nation of Mauritania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: U.N. Body Condemns Torture of Guantánamo Prisoner Awaiting Capital Trial
description: The panel denounced the United States and seven other nations. It also called for the release of Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri, who is accused of orchestrating the bombing of the Navy destroyer Cole.
content: A United Nations human rights panel has issued a damning report that blames the United States and seven other nations for the C.I.A.’s “torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment” of a Saudi prisoner who now awaits a death penalty trial at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Fitzgerald
title: How to Live When You’ve Lost Everything
description: In a new novel by Andre Dubus III, a man searches for hope and dignity after a long run of misfortune.
content: Tom Lowe is, well, low. Destitute. About as close to rock bottom as he can get. He was once a successful carpenter with his own business, a gorgeous house he designed and built himself — with the help of an (eventually disastrous) adjustable-rate mortgage — and a wife and child he adored. Now he’s divorced, estranged from his 19-year-old son and living in Section 8 housing in Amesbury, Mass. Worst of all, Tom, the narrator of Andre Dubus III’s novel “Such Kindness,” isn’t able to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: The Man Reimagining Disney Classics for Today’s World
description: Sean Bailey is in charge of live-action remakes of films like “The Little Mermaid.” It’s a job that puts him in the middle of a partisan divide.
content: For more than a decade, Sean Bailey has run Disney’s animated film “reimagining” factory with quiet efficiency and superhero-sized results. His live-action “Aladdin” collected $1.1 billion at the box office, while a photorealistic “The Lion King” took in $1.7 billion. A live-action “Beauty and the Beast” delivered $1.3 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Peter Simonischek, Beloved Austrian Actor, Is Dead at 76
description: He played a prankster and adoring father in “Toni Erdmann,” the Oscar-nominated 2016 comedy that made him an international star, but he had long been a celebrity at home.
content: Peter Simonischek, an eminent Austrian theater actor who found international fame as the shambolic prankster and adoring father in Maren Ade’s Oscar-nominated 2016 German film “Toni Erdmann,” died on May 29 at his home in Vienna. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
title: Caribou Meat and Moon Signs: Inuit Lessons for Soldiers in the Arctic
description: Humbled by centuries of fatal colonial expeditions, Canada’s military is learning Arctic survival strategies from the austere area’s only inhabitants.
content: A moon dog hung low over the horizon. It showed up on the first day of the Canadian soldiers’ patrol, and the Inuit rangers guiding them in the country’s far north spotted it right away: Ice crystals in the clouds were bending the light, making two illusory moons appear in the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Mets Hall of Fame Class That Specializes in Honesty
description: As the team continues to celebrate its history, Gary Cohen, Howie Rose, Al Leiter and Howard Johnson were honored for their contributions over the years.
content: He sat in the audience watching it all, like a proud grandfather at a college graduation. Fred Wilpon, 86, had owned the Mets when their new class of Hall of Famers — Howard Johnson, Al Leiter and the broadcasters Gary Cohen and Howie Rose — made their marks with the team. At a news conference before the ceremony on Saturday, Wilpon beamed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave, David Pierson and Chris Buckley
title: China and U.S. Lay Out Rival Visions for Asia as Ships Nearly Collide
description: China’s defense minister says the best way to avoid accidental conflict is for countries outside the region, like the United States, to leave and “mind your own business.”
content: Senior military officials from the United States and China used a conference in Singapore to push competing visions of Asia’s future security: a U.S.-led safety net of well-armed partnerships versus a region where China is the center of a new international order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: For Claressa Shields, Repeat Titles Haven’t Come With Knockouts
description: It’s tougher in women’s boxing to get victories by stoppage, which forces champions like Shields to adapt their style.
content: When Claressa Shields threw a looping right hand during her middleweight title defense in Detroit on Saturday night, the punch would sometimes make contact and either clip the jaw of the challenger, Maricela Cornejo, or bounce off her left shoulder.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For Women in Mauritania, Divorce Is Cause for Joy, Not Sorrow
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 4, 2023.
content: “Snapchat is the new ululation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: In a Year of Capitol Feuds, Oregon Has a Political Breakdown
description: Bipartisan collaboration was once a point of pride in Oregon, where Republicans have brought the Senate to a halt with a political boycott.
content: For the past month, the Oregon Senate has started its daily proceedings by dispatching a search party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Michael D. Shear, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Inside the Complicated Reality of Being America’s Oldest President
description: President Biden is asking voters to keep him in the White House until age 86, renewing attention to an issue that polls show troubles most Americans.
content: There was the time last winter when President Biden was awakened at 3 a.m. while on a trip to Asia and told that a missile had struck Poland, touching off a panic that Russia might have expanded the war in Ukraine to a NATO ally. Within hours in the middle of the night, Mr. Biden consulted his top advisers, called the president of Poland and the NATO secretary general, and gathered fellow world leaders to deal with the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Amanda Holpuch
title: Sonic Boom Heard Across D.C. Area Was From Military Jets, Officials Say
description: The noise, which startled residents and shook buildings, was caused by an authorized military flight that responded to an intrusion into restricted airspace, U.S. and military officials said.
content: A loud noise that was heard across much of the Washington, D.C., area on Sunday afternoon was caused by the sonic boom from military jets scrambling to respond to an intrusion into restricted airspace by a private flight, military and U.S. officials confirmed on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marguerite Preston
title: The Sun Is Calling
description: Make your cookout, picnic or beach trip a little easier.
content: It’s June. The weather forecast is starting to look like summer, and I’m looking forward to my favorite sunny-day activity: eating outside.
source.name: The New York Times

title: College Grads, Do ‘Follow Your Passions’
description: Advice for college graduates. Also: Right-to-shelter laws; the work commute; teaching reading; Ron DeSantis and Clarence Thomas.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: For These Bird Flu Researchers, Work Is a Day at the Very ‘Icky’ Beach
description: The H5N1 virus poses “a great unknown threat” to birds and humans alike. Understanding and thwarting it begins with excrement collection.
content: It was a glorious day for field work on the shores of the Delaware Bay. The late afternoon sun cast a warm glow over the gently sloping beach. The receding tide revealed a smattering of shells. The dune grasses rustled in the breeze. The beach vines were in bloom. And the bird droppings were fresh and plentiful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Pompeo
title: It Took Cold Calculations to Get the Story First
description: “Battle of Ink and Ice” revives the headline-grabbing debate over which explorer reached the North Pole soonest — and which newspaper broke the news.
content: It began with a cable. “REACHED NORTH POLE,” the American explorer Frederick Cook wired on Sept. 1, 1909, to James Gorden Bennett Jr., the Paris-based publisher of The New York Herald, which teed up Cook’s 2,000-word “EXCLUSIVE ACCOUNT” of his discovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: A Pacifist Sect From Russia Is Shaken by War, and Modernity
description: The Ukraine conflict is causing soul-searching among the Doukhobors, a peace-loving group that emigrated to Canada in 1899.
content: When he was growing up among the Doukhobors, a pacifist religious group that emigrated to Canada from czarist Russia, J.J. Verigin would sometimes arrive home from school to find naked elderly women trying to burn down his family’s house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: These Activists Distrust Voting Machines. Just Don’t Call Them Election Deniers.
description: As election activists rally against new voting machines, they are drifting into territory now dominated by conspiracy theorists.
content: For decades, Lulu Friesdat made election integrity her life’s work. Drawing support from activists and academics, she co-founded Smart Elections, a nonpartisan group that is opposed to some voting machines that Ms. Friesdat believes would increase wait times and cost a small fortune to purchase and maintain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘Sor Juana’ Review: Undone by Love
description: Ballet Hispánico debuts two works: one about the 17th-century nun and poet Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz, and the other, “Papagayos,” featuring a supernatural hat.
content: In 17th-century Mexico, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz was a nun, a poet, an intellectual, a composer and a defender of women’s rights to education and the pursuit of knowledge. While not obscure, especially not in Mexico, she is something of an enigma, her life and work subject to many interpretations. It’s too bad that “Sor Juana,” a new creation by the choreographer Michelle Manzanales, doesn’t bring her into sharper focus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Amir Hamja
title: What Happened When a Brooklyn Neighborhood Policed Itself for Five Days
description: On a two-block stretch of Brownsville in April, the police stepped aside and let residents respond to 911 calls. It was a bold experiment that some believe could redefine law enforcement in New York City.
content: It had been a quiet April afternoon until about a dozen teenagers began running up Pitkin Avenue in Brownsville, yelling and cursing. They were chasing a girl of about 14 and it was clear they wanted a fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Hundreds Were Mistakenly Told They Might Have Cancer, Test Company Says
description: Grail, which makes a blood test for cancer, said a vendor’s software issue caused inaccurate letters to be sent to about 400 customers last month.
content: A company that developed a blood test that detects dozens of types of cancer has acknowledged that about 400 of its customers were mistakenly told last month that they might have the disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: There are Better Ways to Solve a Housing Crisis Than This
description: The overriding cause of homelessness in New York City is a lack of housing in the region, which has sent rents skyrocketing.
content: Politicians in New York, faced with a housing crisis that has driven more than 80,000 people into homeless shelters and renters to the brink, are simply throwing up their hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Allstate Is No Longer Offering New Policies in California
description: Like State Farm, which announced a similar move last week, Allstate cited worsening climate conditions that had made doing business there difficult.
content: California property owners hoping to open new insurance policies are no longer able to do so with one of the nation’s largest homeowner insurance companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Arabia Says It Will Cut Production to Stem a Slide in Oil Prices
description: OPEC Plus, the group of major oil producers, said it would continue its recent cuts in output, but Saudi Arabia said it would cut further for at least a month.
content: The group of major oil-producing countries known as OPEC Plus agreed on Sunday to embark on a complex effort to adjust production as it aimed to halt the recent slide in oil prices, including an additional cut in output of one million barrels a day by Saudi Arabia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benyamin Cohen
title: Einstein and a Theory of Disinformation
description: Time is relative depending on your frame of reference. Maybe truth is too?
content: A decade ago, Ivanka Trump offered her Twitter followers a bit of wisdom from one of the world’s favorite geniuses to impress her legions of Twitter followers. “If the facts don’t fit the theory, change the facts. — Albert Einstein.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Saporito
title: Could Air Travel Get Even More Miserable? Yes, and Here’s Why.
description: The looming headache of this summer’s travel season only strengthens the argument against the JetBlue/Spirit merger.
content: Were you planning on a last-minute trip to Orlando to visit Gov. Ron DeSantis’s favorite amusement park? “Prices are currently high for your search,” warns Google Flights. Well, yes they are.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: In Israel, Tough Questions Follow Fatal Attack on the Egyptian Border
description: Israeli officials were investigating a series of mishaps and failings that led to the killings of three Israeli soldiers by an Egyptian border guard.
content: A breached emergency gate at Israel’s southern border with Egypt that was held closed only with plastic handcuffs; the passage of hours before two Israeli soldiers’ bodies were discovered; and the botched pursuit of an infiltrator that led to the death of a third soldier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Chuck Todd to Leave ‘Meet the Press’
description: He will be succeeded by Kristen Welker, NBC’s chief White House correspondent and the co-anchor of “Weekend Today.”
content: Chuck Todd said on Sunday that he was stepping down from NBC’s “Meet the Press” after nine years in the moderator’s chair and would be succeeded by the network’s chief White House correspondent, Kristen Welker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir, Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
title: India Vows Punishment for Those Responsible for Deadly Train Crash
description: Officials suggested human error, even sabotage, could have led to the crash that killed 275, as crews raced to restore service and families struggled to reach the site to identify loved ones.
content: The crushed train cars were cleared and the jumbled tracks straightened and rejoined, as workers labored on Sunday to quickly restore an important rail line in east India two days after the country’s worst train disaster in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The Big Number: 49%
description: Cubicles sit empty and office pantries wait for the one day a week when their workers might actually come in. Here’s what office life looks like today.
content: Cubicles sit empty and office pantries wait for the one day a week when their workers might actually come in. Here’s what office life looks like today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Lazaro Gamio, Marco Hernandez, Scott Reinhard, Karan Deep Singh and Sameer Yasir
title: How the India Train Crash Unfolded
description: The sequence of events as three trains collided in one of India’s deadliest rail accidents.
content: The sequence of events as three trains collided in one of India’s deadliest rail accidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Hundreds of Thousands March Against Poland’s Governing Party
description: Supporters and members of opposition parties protested against the conservative Law and Justice party in Poland’s largest antigovernment gathering in years.
content: Supporters and members of opposition parties protested against the conservative Law and Justice party in Poland’s largest antigovernment gathering in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Hong Kong Police Tighten Security on Tiananmen Square Anniversary
description: The police searched bags and detained demonstrators, including the pro-democracy activist Alexandra Wong, on the anniversary of China’s Tiananmen Square massacre.
content: The police searched bags and detained demonstrators, including the pro-democracy activist Alexandra Wong, on the anniversary of China’s Tiananmen Square massacre.
source.name: The New York Times
